Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They develop a floor plan for a new office, ensuring workspaces accommodate employees’ needs efficiently.
Story: I sat at the dining table, my laptop open beside a half-eaten plate of pasta. My family’s voices swirled around me, laughter and suggestions bouncing off the walls as they debated where to go this weekend. My younger sister nudged me, “You have to come this time. We haven’t all been together in ages.” I smiled, trying to sound enthusiastic, but my mind kept drifting back to the office floor plan glowing on my screen. The deadline was tight, and I still hadn’t figured out how to fit the break area without sacrificing workspace. My boss expected nothing less than perfection, and I knew every detail mattered. Yet, my family’s hopeful eyes pulled at me, expecting me to be present, to join in the fun and make memories. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—one demanding my creativity and focus, the other my warmth and presence. My heart raced as I tried to listen to both, feeling the tension build, knowing I couldn’t give either what they truly wanted at the same time.
